program_name: Term Dynamic Load Management and Auto Dynamic Load Management
description: Con Edison's Term-DLM and Auto-DLM are long-term contract-based demand response programs established by the New York Public Service Commission in September 2020. Term-DLM is a day-ahead peak-shaving program requiring 21 hours advance notice, while Auto-DLM is a rapid-response program requiring only 10 minutes advance notice. Both programs offer 3-5 year contracts providing longer-term price certainty compared to tariff-based programs like CSRP. These programs were designed to drive investment in energy storage and other long-term demand response resources by providing multi-year revenue commitments.

utilities: Consolidated Edison Company of New York (Con Edison)

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Minimum 50 kW total load reduction required. Both aggregators and direct participants must meet this threshold. Direct participants may self-aggregate multiple accounts as long as they are not acting as a third-party aggregator.

notification.notification_notes: Term-DLM: 21 hours advance notice (day-ahead). Auto-DLM: 10 minutes advance notice for rapid response to system contingencies.

capacity_rate.capacity_rate_notes: Capacity payment rates are determined through competitive bidding process (pay-as-bid). Applicants submit their own $/kW incentive rate bid for each aggregation. Specific clearing prices not publicly disclosed. Term-DLM is valued similarly to CSRP (which ranges $6-18/kW-month depending on location). Auto-DLM receives premium payment above CSRP+DLRP combined value due to rapid-response capability, but specific premium rates not available.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Penalties likely apply for non-performance during called events, but specific penalty structure not available in public documentation.

bonus_payments.description: Increased reservation payment for high-event years
bonus_payments.conditions: During a Capability Period that includes five or more Contingency and Immediate Events, the reservation payment increases by $5/kW-month beginning with the first month in which five or more program-year cumulative events occurred in the network.

payment_structure.payment_notes: Pay-as-bid procurement mechanism. Contract terms of 3-5 years provide long-term price certainty. Term-DLM valued as CSRP equivalent. Auto-DLM valued as CSRP + DLRP combined due to dual capability.

call_windows.notes: Auto-DLM: 6:00 AM - 12:00 AM (midnight), seven days per week. Available for rapid response to local system contingencies.

event_parameters.event_parameters_notes: Term-DLM: 4-hour events in fixed call windows on weekdays with 21 hours notice. Auto-DLM: 4-hour events available 18 hours/day (6 AM-midnight), 7 days/week, with only 10 minutes notice. Specific annual event/hour limits not available in public documentation.

nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: Competitive pay-as-bid procurement. Applicants submit: (1) Amount of Load Relief (kW) they will provide, (2) Network location, (3) Incentive Rate per kW per Capability Period, (4) Supporting information. Clearing mechanism is pay-as-bid with bids to nearest dollar.
nomination_bidding.nomination_notes: RFP issued for 2026 and 2027 capability periods. Contract terms between 3-5 years. First procurement launched 2020, ongoing annual solicitations.

special_attributes: Designed to incentivize energy storage deployment

program_evolution.change_description: New York PSC Order (September 17, 2020) established Term-DLM and Auto-DLM programs with minimum 3-year contracts to drive energy storage investment and provide longer-term revenue certainty.
CPower selected as aggregator partner for initial Term-DLM deployment by Con Edison and National Grid.

2024 Capability Period performance: Term-DLM had 708 enrollments with 20.40 MW pledged and 32.29 MW delivered (158% performance). Auto-DLM had 4 enrollments with 11.50 MW pledged and 12.83 MW delivered (112% performance). Five Term-DLM events called.
RFP issued for 2026 and 2027 capability periods. Submission deadline February 7, 2025.

key_differences: Contract Structure: CSRP is open tariff program with annual pricing changes. Term-DLM offers 3-5 year fixed contracts.
Procurement: CSRP is tariff-based enrollment. Term-DLM uses competitive bidding.
Notice Period: CSRP typically 21+ hours notice. Term-DLM same (21 hours).
Revenue Certainty: Term-DLM provides multi-year price lock vs CSRP annual uncertainty.
Valuation: Term-DLM valued similarly to CSRP for bid evaluation purposes.
Payment Rates: CSRP pays $6-18/kW-month (location-dependent) plus $1/kWh performance. Term-DLM rates determined by competitive bid.
Event Windows: CSRP weekdays only. Term-DLM weekdays only in 4-hour fixed windows.
Response Time: DLRP provides faster response than CSRP. Auto-DLM even faster (10 minutes).
Availability: DLRP typically more limited availability than Auto-DLM's 18 hours/day, 7 days/week.
Payment: DLRP pays $18-25/kW-month (tier-dependent) plus $1/kWh. Auto-DLM rates via competitive bid.
Valuation: Auto-DLM valued as combined CSRP + DLRP capabilities.

tier_system.tier_description: Con Edison's service territory is divided into electrical networks, each assigned to Tier 1 or Tier 2. Tier 2 networks are higher priority for demand response due to greater system need and receive higher incentive rates.
tier_system.tier_notes: For 2025: Park Slope and Richmond Hill networks upgraded to Tier 2. Riverdale and Southeast Bronx networks reverted to Tier 1. Network assignments to specific call windows updated annually and posted by January 1.

integration_metadata.notes: High-quality program structure with clear eligibility and event parameters. Competitive bidding rates not publicly disclosed reduces transparency. Strong fit for battery energy storage systems due to multi-year revenue certainty and dual program options (Term-DLM for day-ahead optimization, Auto-DLM for premium rapid-response revenue). Networks require communicating interval meters. Auto-DLM particularly valuable for fast-responding BESS assets. Some details (annual event limits, specific penalty structure) not available in public documentation.
